citation.article-title: Shewanella olleyana sp. nov., a marine species isolated from a temperate estuary which produces high levels of polyunsaturated fatty acids.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Shewanella olleyana sp. nov.
Shewanella olleyana (ol.ley'a.na. N.L. fem. adj. olleyana named for June Olley for her contributions to food microbiology)
Cells are roD-shaped, Gram-negative, 1-2 μm in length, 0.4-0.5 μm in diameter and have a single polar flagellum.
Temperature range for growth is 2-30 °C.
Optimum temperature for growth was 20-22 °C.
Requires Na+ ions for growth (minimum 0.35 M, optimal 0.4-0.6 M, maximum 1.1 M).
Oxidase- and catalasepositive.
Facultatively anaerobic chemoheterotroph.
Can grow anaerobically by respiration using Fe(III), Mn(IV), nitrate, thiosulfate, trimethylamine N-oxide and AQDS as electron acceptors and lactate as an electron donor.
Carbohydates are not fermented.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite in the presence of oxygen.
Arginine dihydrolase, ornithine decarboxylase and lysine decarboxylase are not produced.
Hydrolyses Tween 80, gelatin, starch, alginate and aesculin but not carboxymethylcellulose, chitin, dextran, casein, elastin, DNA or uric acid.
Weakly agarolytic.
Production of H2S from L-cysteine is negative (from API 20E test strip results) but H2S was formed from thiosulfate anaerobically.
Negative for tryptophan deaminase and β-galactosidase.
Indole is not formed from L-tryptophan.
Voges-Proskauer test is negative.

In addition to the carbon source utilization data shown in Table 1, D-fructose, D-galactose, m-erythritol, glycerol, DL-malate, L-glutamate, L-phenylalanine, L-tyrosine and tannic acid were used as sole carbon and energy sources.

The utilization of D-melibiose, DL-β-hydroxybutyrate, fumarate and succinate was variable between strains while L-arabinose, lactose, D-mannose, D-mannitol, D-sorbitol, caproate, citrate and phenylacetate were not utilized.
Forms tan-coloured, butyrous, regular, convex, undulate, opaque colonies 2-4 mm in diameter following 24 h incubation at 20 °C.
Major fatty acids are i13:0, i15:0, 16:0, 16: 1(n-7), 18:1(n-7) and 20:5(n-3) (Table 2).
Based on 16S rDNA nucleotide sequence analysis, the species belongs to the family Alteromonadaceae, order `Alteromonadales' and class `Gammaproteobacteria'.
The type strain is ACEM 9T (=ACAM 644T=LMG 21437T) isolated from saline waters of the Huon River estuary, Tasmania, Australia.
